fase.title: Frontier AI System Evaluations
fase.description: FASE is an initiative to develop evolving, community-driven evaluation frameworks for AI. The project builds domain-specific benchmarks, simulators for autonomous AI systems, and methodological standards for rigorous assessment. By enabling open contribution and structured collaboration, FASE supports the creation of reliable, extensible testing grounds for advancing AI capabilities in complex environments.

vlm_calibration.title: VLM Calibration
vlm_calibration.description: The VLM Calibration Project investigates whether large language models can accurately assess the correctness of their own answers. Despite impressive capabilities, VLMs often exhibit overconfidence; even when wrong. This project systematically evaluates model calibration across multiple datasets and architectures, probing the reliability of their self-assessed confidence. By analyzing when and why different models misjudge uncertainty, we aim to improve trust and interpretability in AI systems.

github_link.title: GitHub
github_link.description: View the VLM Calibration code on GitHub

multimodal_action_models.title: Multimodal Action Models
multimodal_action_models.description: The Multimodal Action Models project aims to develop AI systems that link perception to action across diverse modalities such as vision, language and sensor data to perform complex tasks in dynamic physical and digital environments.

rapid_reconfiguration.title: Rapid Reconfiguration
rapid_reconfiguration.description: Rapid Reconfiguration develops planning and coordination strategies for modular robotic collectives to change global shape quickly and reliably.

autonomous_self_repair.title: Autonomous Self-Repair
autonomous_self_repair.description: Autonomous Self-Repair develops damage-aware strategies that allow modular robotic structures to detect failures and reorganize without human intervention.

autonomous_assembly_of_modular_space_str.title: Autonomous Assembly of Modular Space Structures
autonomous_assembly_of_modular_space_str.description: Autonomous Assembly of Modular Space Structures develops coordination, planning, and control strategies for free-flying modular spacecraft to assemble large structures in orbit.

cooperative_object_transportation_in_orb.title: Cooperative Object Transportation in Orbit
cooperative_object_transportation_in_orb.description: Cooperative Object Transportation in Orbit develops coordinated autonomy for teams of spacecraft to move, handoff, and position objects in space.

navigation_in_crowded_orbital_environmen.title: Navigation in Crowded Orbital Environments
navigation_in_crowded_orbital_environmen.description: Navigation in Crowded Orbital Environments develops scalable autonomy for spacecraft operating amid debris, traffic, and other agents in dense orbital regimes.

golem.label: GOLEM
golem.title: GOLEM
golem.description: GOLEM (Generalist Omnimodal Learning in Engineered Minds) is a long term research program focused on building AI systems that can perceive, reason, adapt, and act across any input and output modality. The program explores fundamental architectures, training methodologies, and evaluation frameworks needed for AI systems that can process multimodal inputs, generate appropriate outputs, adapt to new situations, and continue learning over time.

holon.label: Holon
holon.title: Holon
holon.description: Holon is a long-horizon robotics program focused on cellular, modular robotic systems that can behave as programmable matter. Rather than treating robots as fixed assemblies, Holon explores collectives of simple robotic cells that can reorganize their structure, function, and resource allocation in response to task demands and unexpected damage. Inspired by biological systems, the program targets three foundational capabilities: morphogenesis, the ability to form and transform global structure through local interactions; homeostasis, the ability to detect damage and preserve function through self-repair and reorganization; and metabolism, the ability to manage energy, material, and functional roles over time. Together, these capabilities aim to enable resilient, adaptive machines capable of long-duration operation in extreme and uncertain environments.

rapid_reconfiguration.title: Rapid Reconfiguration
rapid_reconfiguration.description: Massively parallel shape change for modular robotic systems.

the_orbital_yard.label: The Orbital Yard
the_orbital_yard.title: The Orbital Yard
the_orbital_yard.description: The Orbital Yard is a research program focused on enabling autonomous, scalable construction in orbit. Many critical space systems, such as large solar power arrays, orbital factories, and kilometer-scale telescopes, are too large or fragile to launch fully assembled and must instead be built in space. Existing approaches rely on centralized, single-purpose systems constrained by launch geometry and cannot scale to meet these demands. The program develops the core primitives required for autonomous in-space construction, including autonomous modular structure assembly, cooperative transportation and handoff of large objects, and safe navigation in dense orbital environments. Together, these capabilities form a technical foundation for persistent orbital construction sites, orbital shipyards, and future large-scale space infrastructure.
